name: iter::adapters::map_windows::Buffer::<T, N>::try_from_iter

array::iter_next_chunk.doc:
Pulls `N` items from `iter` and returns them as an array. If the iterator
 yields fewer than `N` items, `Err` is returned containing an iterator over
 the already yielded items.

 Since the iterator is passed as a mutable reference and this function calls
 `next` at most `N` times, the iterator can still be used afterwards to
 retrieve the remaining items.

 If `iter.next()` panics, all items already yielded by the iterator are
 dropped.

 Used for [`Iterator::next_chunk`].

mem::maybe_uninit::MaybeUninit::<T>::new.doc:
Creates a new `MaybeUninit<T>` initialized with the given value.
 It is safe to call [`assume_init`] on the return value of this function.

 Note that dropping a `MaybeUninit<T>` will never call `T`'s drop code.
 It is your responsibility to make sure `T` gets dropped if it got initialized.

 # Example

 ```
 use std::mem::MaybeUninit;

 let v: MaybeUninit<Vec<u8>> = MaybeUninit::new(vec![42]);
 # // Prevent leaks for Miri
 # unsafe { let _ = MaybeUninit::assume_init(v); }
 ```

 [`assume_init`]: MaybeUninit::assume_init
